elements.title: Mount Okmok (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Mount Okmok (pictured) in Alaska may have contributed to the downfall of Ptolemaic Egypt?

elements.title: Majed Abu Maraheel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Majed Abu Maraheel, the first Palestinian Olympian, tended flowers for a living before becoming an Olympic runner?

elements.title: Lunar Seismic Profiling Experiment (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Apollo 17 carried a 6-pound (2.7 kg) explosive charge as part of the Lunar Seismic Profiling Experiment?

elements.title: Edwin Atwater (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Edwin Atwater and his brother were the first people to import glass into Canada?

elements.title: U.S. Route 101 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a former section of U.S. Route 101 was nicknamed the "Bloody Bayshore" for its frequent collisions?

elements.title: Gerald Willis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Gerald Willis, after working as a bus driver at age 15, started a business that earned $2 million per year and built a replica of the Hermitage after watching The President's Lady?

elements.title: Muckrach Castle (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ian Begg restored Muckrach Castle after over 200 years without a roof?

elements.title: John Jones (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that John Jones took a leave of absence just days before succeeding Bob Harlan as chief executive officer of the Green Bay Packers, and ultimately left the team a few months later?

elements.title: Snake Saturday (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Missouri's annual Snake Saturday parade originally began in a hotel parking lot with only four floats?
